ALLEGATION:
A Child Caring Institution’s (CCI) facility staff and Wayne County-Department of
Health and Human Services (DHHS) foster care workers were on Teams for a
Family Team Meeting (FTM) recently regarding Youth A. The Foster Care Worker
(FCW) indicated something to the effect that they intentionally did not document a
need for one-to-one supervision on the youth’s CCI intake paperwork because “we
know everyone will turn her down and won’t take her”.
INVESTIGATION:
On 9/22/2022 I spoke with CCI facility Director 1 by telephone. I also spoke with
Director 2 by telephone this same date. Both Directors reported the agency
received information on Youth A from DHHS-NC prior to Youth A’s placement at the
facility. They reported a third facility person, CCI Staff 3 would have copies of those
documents.
Director 1
Director 1 reported Youth A is in placement with their CCI facility (CCI X). Youth A
was placed with CCI X from the Detroit Behavior Institute (DBI) agency after DBI
closed. Director 1 reported they requested Youth A’s removal from their program via
a 30-day removal because Youth A’s needs are outside of their agency’s placement
capabilities. They requested an FTM with DHHS because of Youth A’s ongoing
behaviors; and they wanted to check in on the 30-day removal request submitted to
3

DHHS. The FTM occurred via TEAMs and Director 1 reported being on the TEAMs
call. During the TEAMs discussion about Youth A, Director 1 reported bringing up
that their agency was not fully aware all of Youth A’s issues. A DHHS-NC staff
members responded with a comment something to the effect that “I do not think we
put on the paperwork that she needed 1:1 supervision; I don’t think we should put on
that she needs 1:1 because that will limit our ability to get a placement”. Director 1
did not know which DHHS-NC staff person made the comment, but she did not
believe it was Youth A’s FCW. She reported there being 12 people on the TEAMs
call. Director 1 reported being frustrated by that comment; but reported someone
else stated that was not a wise recommendation. Director 1 expressed concern that
DHHS-NC’s possible lack of transparency may be the reason Youth A is being
bounced around in placements.
Director 2
Director 2 reported being on two different FTM/RPU (Residential Placement Unit)
meetings scheduled by DHHS-NC, 9/6/2022 and 9/16/2022. Director 2 was not
certain of all of the DHHS staff members on the FTM calls. On 9/27/2022 she
provided me a copy of the TEAMs invite that listed the members invited/included.
She reported those members were included/invited for both meetings.
Director 2 reported Youth A’s placement needs and behaviors were discussed at
both meetings. Director 2 reported Youth A’s FCW did not make the comment that
was indicated in the complaint. Nor did Director 2 recall any DHHS-NC staff person
making such a statement or comment. Director 2 said she only recalled someone
saying something like “It a catch 22” situation; that they want to provide residential
facilities with all information about Youth A’s behaviors but doing so presents
placement barriers. One of the DHHS-NC staff, whom Director 2 did not know, said
they know Youth A has all these behaviors, but with the mention of these behaviors,
a lot of people will turn Youth A down. Director 2 recalled someone from CCI X
saying that there are behaviors that Youth A has that were not put in the referral.
Director 2 did not recall a DHHS-NC staff person response to that comment from her
agency; but she stated she did not feel DHHS-NC “intentionally left anything out of
the paperwork.”
CCI Staff 3
On 9/27/2022 I interviewed CCI Staff 3 by telephone. She recalled FTM meetings
with DHHS-NC staff as 9/9/2022 and 9/16/2022. With the latter TEAM’s meeting
being the one whereby the youth’s behavior and statement over one-one supervision
came up. She affirmed Director 1’s reporting related to the purpose of the FTM
meeting. And that she, Director 1 and Director 2 attended the TEAM’s meeting from
CCI X. She reported Supervisor B, Specialist D, Supervisor E and Manager F and
Manager G were on the call from DHHS-NC. She said FCW C was not in attendance
or had not been in attendance in its entirety. CCI Staff 3 reported that Supervisor B
did most of the talking from DHHS-NC’s end, with Specialist D sometimes
commenting also.
4

CCI Staff 3 reported during the meeting CCI X expressed concern with Youth A’s
escalating behaviors, and DHHS-NC indicated other agencies were denying
placement of Youth A due to those behaviors. CCI Staff 3 reported their staff
expressed their appreciation for the department’s difficulties in trying to secure a
placement but reiterated that Youth A’s 30-days were up; CCI X not being equipped
to handle Youth A’s behaviors; that Youth A requires a more secure program. CCI
Staff 3 reported at some point a DHHS-NC staff (CCI Staff 3 did not know who)
asked them whether they could do 1:1 supervision with Youth A; and they explained
they could not and would not be able to provide that degree of services. Director 2
asked whether DHHS-NC could provide staff to aid in providing the 1:1 staff, and
Supervisor B stated that they did not have the staff to do that. CCI Staff 3 said
Specialist D and Supervisor E interjected and repeated what Supervisor B stated
about the 1:1.
CCI Staff 3 advised that during the meeting they were trying to get across what was
happening with Youth A, and that Youth A’s behaviors warranted the extra attention
and that other agencies being explored for placement for Youth A needed to know
that. CCI Staff 3 reported it was at that point that Supervisor B stated, “We are not
putting that down”. CCI Staff 3 was not sure if “We are not putting that down” meant
Supervisor B would not put in a referral that Youth A needed 1:1 supervision or
something different. CCI Staff 3 reported when Supervisor B made that statement,
Supervisor B and other DHHS-NC staff were talking amongst themselves. She
reported it was then that Director 1 interjected and indicated to DHHS-NC that the
department needs to be transparent about Youth A's issues and behaviors, that this
might be why Youth A passes from placement to placement. CCI Staff 3 said
DHHS-NC did not reply back to Director 1 but asked them about taking Youth A to
the hospital when episodes occur, and thereon, their meeting discussion centered
around that.
I asked CCI Staff 3 whether Youth A’s extensive behaviors and needs were
indicated on the referral/package of documentation provided to CCI X from DHHS-
C. CCI Staff 3 admitted to getting lots of file documents on Youth A. She/CCI X
provided me a copy of the documents on 9/27/2022. CCI Staff 3 also advised they
took Youth A from DBI, and some of the paper work they received on Youth A
included documents from that facility. She reported when FCW C dropped Youth A
off, FCW C reported just getting Youth A’s case; and did not know much about her at
that time.
DHHS-NC onsite agency visit
On 10/4/2022 I made an onsite DHHS-NC agency visit at which time I interviewed
Supervisor B and FCW 3. Both of these staff persons acknowledged a TEAM’s
meeting with CCI X staff on 9/16/2022 related to placement and behavioral issues
for Youth A.. Both of these staff persons reported 1:1 supervision was something
they had offered CCI X multiple times. Both also denied the allegations.
5

• Supervisor B reported being present for the entirety of the meeting, and to
FCW C coming in and out of the meeting. She affirmed, Supervisor E’s,
Manager F’s and Manager G’s attendance on the calls, as well as Manager
H’s. She admitted there was discussion about 1:1 supervision for Youth A’s
behaviors, as well as, around the agency’s utilizing the hospital, as needed
related to mental health issues. She also reported there had been
discussion with the agency around Youth A’s placement at DBI and how
Youth A was not on 1:1 supervision at that facility. She reported information
related to Youth A’s behaviors would have been provided to CCI X by RPU
prior to Youth A’s placement at CCI X. Supervisor B denied anyone
indicating to the agency during the meeting that there would not be full
disclosure to referral agencies around Youth A’s behavior. She admitted a
statement was made by Specialist D that if 1:1 supervision is placed on the
referral they would not find many placements because not many agencies
can take a youth needing 1:1 supervision. Supervisor B reported Specialist
D’s statement was made in relation to Specialist D trying to be strength-based
by explaining to the agency that Youth A’s strengths would be highlighted; not
that negative behaviors would not be documented via her referral
documentation. Supervisor B denied herself or anyone saying we are not
putting that down related to behaviors and needs for Youth A.
• Foster Care Worker (FCW) C affirmed being the current FCW for Youth A.
She reported the TEAM’s meeting on 9/16/2022 was one of DHHS-NC’s
check ins with CCI X due to behaviors being reported by CCI X for Youth A,
and the agency’s request for Youth A’s replacement. FCW C affirmed not
being in attendance for the entire meeting; but denied ever hearing anyone
state they would intentionally not put on referral paper work that Youth A
needs 1:1 supervision. FCW C reported DHHS-NC has had outside
discussions around the possible damage to Youth A’s placement chances if
that type of information is on referral package paperwork. She advised that
was due to the fact it’s not certain Youth A needs 1:1 supervision; because
although CCI X reports Youth A needs 1:1 supervision, another agency may
be able to meet Youth A’s need without that level of supervision.
Specialist D
On 10/17/2022 I interviewed Specialist D via TEAMs on 10/17/2022 in the presence
of her supervisor, Supervisor E who was present as a support person to Specialist
D. Both staff persons acknowledged being on the 9/16/2022 TEAM’s call/meeting
with CCI X.
Specialist D denied the allegations. She reported there was a lot of frustration on the
call from CCI X; and CCI X was not happy with some of DHHS-NC answers. She
reported DHHS-NC were not saying to CCI X that DHHS-NC would not be putting
into their referral all of Youth A’s negative behaviors issues and needs. The concern
was that “we wanted to put in strengths” for Youth A (which CCI X could not list one)
so that that would help in securing Youth A a placement. Specialist D advised that
6

in referring Youth A/any youth for residential placement they would include that
information. She said they would also provide a summary statement. She reported
the summary statement is intended to be a brief and quick introduction to the youth,
not a complete detail of the youth’s needs or issues. She reported that would be so
that the residential agency can review the document package, which includes
documents provided from the past placements, and any possible agency can “make
the call and decide if they can meet/service” Youth A needs.
Reviewed:
Youth A’s MISACWIS case record on 9/22/2022 which showed:
• She came into care in August 2018. She is a permanent court ward.
• She was placed at CCI X on 7/7/2022; and discharged 10/9/2022.
• She has had numerous residential and hospital placements in the past.
• Her specialized diagnoses included Post Traumatic Stress Disorder-Chronic,
and Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder, physical and sexual abuse and
substance abuse.
• Her last psychiatric evaluation at the time was from DBI dated 3/24/2022.
DHHS-1105 for 9/16/2022 Team meeting.
A 9/27/2022 email from CCI X with copies of the referral documents they reported
receiving from DHHS-NC on Youth A, outside of the 3600-placement authorization
and consent paperwork:
• Adoption Recruitment Readiness Assessment Monthly Report for 6/9/2022.
• A Children’s Traumatic Assessment Report dated 3/27/2019.
• A psychotropic medication informed consent document dated 11/23/2021 that
listed medications Youth A had been prescribed.
• A DBI 3/24/2022 psychiatric evaluation report, that defined various diagnoses
as listed in this review section.
• Various incident reports from DBI that documented incidents of Youth A
fighting and physically assaulting her peers.
• An IEP Team’s report.
• A 4/21/2022 medication review.
• The Removal petition.
• A 1/29/2022-4/28/2022 Updated service plan and treatment plan for Youth A
that documented:
➢ Diagnoses for Youth A, inclusive of nocturnal enuresis, learning
difficulties, past abuses, oppositional defiant disorder, attention deficit
hyperactivity disorder.
➢ Past Juvenile Detention Facility admission after a 1/19/2022 physical
aggression toward staff and property destruction.
A 10/27/2022 email from Specialist D was received outlining the summary statement
that she includes along with the documents’ package. The latter of which she
indicated includes the initial service plans, updated service plans, incident reports,
trauma assessment, maximus assessment, medication and educational information,
7

etc., that is sent to RPU when the county makes the referral in searching for a
residential placement for Youth A. She reported their unit adds or deletes items with
each new referral depending on updated information received from the current
placement at the time of the referral. Specialist D reported the summary is intended
to be a brief and quick introduction to the youth, not a complete detail of the youth’s
needs or issues. The summary statement she sent out with the document package
was as follows:
• RPU is searching for a residential for:
• Youth A, 14-year-old female out of Wayne County. Youth A is an MCI ward.
• Youth A is described as extremely resilient and is able to advocate for herself
and bounce back quickly from adversity. Youth A enjoys dancing a lot per her
team.
• Youth A is said to be very sweet and easy to talk with. It is said that when
she is de-escalated she is very easily redirected. Youth A is able to advocate
for herself. She enjoys shopping and listening to music.
• Youth A has an uncle out of state that is willing to take placement of her. The
ICPC (Interstate compact on the placement of children) is submitted, and the
county is waiting to hear back regarding the updates.
• Youth A is diagnosed with Major Depression Disorder. Youth A is currently at
Holy Cross Residential, and they are asking for her to be removed. Holy
Cross stated that Youth A’s behaviors included destruction of property, verbal
and physical aggression, AWOLing, and displaying sexual behaviors with
other peers.
• It is to be noted that since being in residential Youth A is starting to feel
hopeless about the move to her uncle’s home. The county and residential
agency feel Youth A is getting anxious and is showing it through her actions.
It is noteworthy, as indicated above that included with this RPU summary statement are
documents from the youth’s past placements, inclusive of service plans, psychological
reports, medication and education information, behavior and incident reports from Youth
A’s prior placements and current placement agency.
8

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12207 Staff responsibilities.
(3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
directly responsible for all of the following activities:
(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the
children, their families, and other relevant individuals
and be primarily responsible for the development,
implementation, and review of service plans for the
children and their families.
ANALYSIS: Based on interviews there is insufficient evidence to support the
allegation; or of the department not providing factual information
and documentation of Youth A behaviors and needs. Nor that
the agency workers did not work directly with other relevant
individuals for the development and implementation of the
service plan for the Youth A.
Technical assistance
The agency is apprised that its summary statement of Youth A
though reported to be designed to be strength-based, and a
quick introduction to the youth, does not fully encompass the
extend of Youth A’s special needs. The statement as outline
might be viewed as the agency not being fully transparent about
the youth’s over-all issues. The summary must also be more
reflective of the youths’ limitations/overall needs.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that no change be made to the license of this child placing
agency.
